audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 45 minutes; modeling, guided practice, quick check.
teacher_notes.materials: Projector, highlighters, short passages with evidence lines.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check and explanation of one elimination.

learning_objectives: Restate the claim before scanning for proof.
Select the sentence that directly supports the claim.
Eliminate statements that are true but irrelevant.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Textual)
objectives: Predict the needed proof in simple words.
Locate the sentence that proves the claim.
Avoid proximity bias-closest line isn’t always best.

lecture_script.script: Underline the claim and predict the proof. Then pick the sentence that most directly proves that prediction.
If the claim says ‘conditions forced a retreat,’ I search for the sentence that names the exact condition causing the retreat.
Raise the letter of the option that proves the claim, not one that’s merely interesting.

worked_example.passage: Although the plan was meticulous, the hikers turned back when an early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
worked_example.question: Which choice best supports the claim that conditions forced a retreat?

options.B: An early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
options.D: The pass is popular in summer.

worked_example.explanation: Only B directly states the condition that caused the retreat.

practice_set.passage: The curator kept the painting in low light because aged pigments faded under stronger lamps.
practice_set.question: Which choice best supports the claim that preservation drove the decision?

unit_check.question: True but irrelevant lines should be

homework: Complete six evidence items; write the predicted proof before choosing.
For two missed items, explain why the chosen line was irrelevant.
Summarize one passage’s claim in seven words or fewer.
